docs.lead_paragraph: Black women are half as likely as white women to breast-feed their babies, a difference that may contribute to higher infant mortality among blacks, researchers reported yesterday. Writing in the journal Pediatrics, researchers from Brigham Young University said federal health surveys showed that while 65 percent of white women reported having breast-fed, only 30 percent of blacks did. The difference remained, the study said, even after researchers factored out variables like education, income level and age.

headline.main: Breast-Feeding Found to Vary by Race

docs.lead_paragraph: I went to the genetics clinic the same way I approached most scary medical moments: dressed to run. After every angst-provoking mammogram, each ominous diagnosis in a relative too young and too close, one sister's ovarian cancer and another's death from breast cancer at 34, a good long run has been both my therapy and my escape. Now, my faded running shoes felt sutured to the floor.

headline.main: Sometimes, It's the Good News That Makes the Patient Feel So Bad

docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors have long known that high blood pressure can lead to strokes, but why some people with hypertension have them and others do not is not clear. A new study suggests that personality may play an important role. In the current issue of the journal Stroke, researchers report that men who handle stress poorly appear to be at higher risk. The authors, from Lund University in Sweden, said that their findings might make it possible to identify people at higher risk and give them behavioral counseling. The lead researcher was Dr. Lena Andre-Petersson.

headline.main: Personality May Play a Role in Strokes

docs.lead_paragraph: The ''E'' rating for video games stands for ''everyone,'' meaning that everyone can play without reason for concern. But parents who do not want their children exposed to violence should be aware that ''E'' ratings do not provide that guarantee, researchers warn.

headline.main: In Some Games, 'E' Isn't for Enlightened

docs.abstract: Researchers warn that parents who do not want their children exposed to violence in video games should be aware that 'E' rating, meaning for 'everyone,' does not provide such a guarantee (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Still looking for an effective and harmless way to keep mosquitoes from spoiling your summer? Get a cow or a pig. No kidding. Given a choice, the females of almost every mosquito species studied greatly preferred their blood to ours. Even a dog can help, though it's almost as painful to see my dog surrounded by a horde of winged beasts, especially when they realize that his eyelids provide easier access to his blood than his thick coat.

headline.main: Simple Steps Can Keep Biting Pests at Bay

docs.lead_paragraph: Allowing drug addicts to exchange old needles for new ones has been shown to reduce needle sharing, a major source of H.I.V. infection, researchers from the University of California at Davis reported in the current issue of the journal AIDS. The lead author, Dr. David R. Gibson, and his colleagues based their findings on a review of 42 studies, published from 1989 to 1999, that looked at needle exchange programs. Twenty-eight found a clear reduction in the risk of H.I.V. infection, the report said, while 12 found no effect or were equivocal and 2 found an increased risk. The Davis researchers, however, found that flaws in the studies with neutral or unfavorable findings might have masked the benefits of needle exchange.

headline.main: A Closer Look at Needle Exchanges

docs.lead_paragraph: Mindy Prager, a psychiatrist who turns 40 this year, is trying to have a baby. Like many other women who delayed pregnancy, she has several concerns. She wonders if she is too old to begin motherhood, if she is still fertile and if her boyfriend of four years is as committed to the idea as she is. But Dr. Prager also has other things on her mind. She will need artificial insemination to conceive, and if it works she will have to balance the needs of pregnancy with the handful of pills she needs every day to stay alive. Dr. Prager is H.I.V. positive.

headline.main: Women Now Look Beyond H.I.V., to Children and Grandchildren

docs.abstract: Small but increasing number of HIV-positive women are deciding to have children; now, with regimen of medication, an HIV-positive woman can reduce chance of infecting her child to almost zero; examples cited; photos (M) (Article in series AIDS at 20)

docs.lead_paragraph: For travelers to countries where malaria is a concern, federal health officials warn that antimalarial drugs are not all alike, and it is essential that the right one be prescribed. In two cases this year, American travelers sought medication before their trips -- a standard practice for people who want to avoid malaria -- but died of the disease shortly after returning home, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

headline.main: A Crucial Difference in Malaria Drugs
